title: You Are What You Tweet: Analyzing Twitter for Public Health

author: Michael J. Paul, Department of Computer Science, Johns Hopkins University

segmentation: So my name is Michael.
This is joint work with Mark Trezzi at Johns Hopkins.
So the goal of this project was to see if there's a signal in the Twitter stream that we can detect that can tell us something about the health of a population.
And if so, we want to know what health issues and what illnesses people are talking about on Twitter.
And we want to know if there is some useful information we can extract from that.
So I'll motivate this with a very brief history of related work.
So a few years ago, Google released the service that they call flu trends, which many of you have probably seen.
So the idea is they discovered that certain search queries are highly correlated with the rate of the flu.
So for example, if someone is searching for flu medicine, that's evidence that they might have the flu.
And so these researchers were able to build a model that can predict the rate of influenza first first in the United States, but I believe they do it worldwide now.
So this is great.
This is useful because this model is real time, so it can take up to two weeks for governments to compile and collect records from clinics.

Whereas with Google you get this right away, but the downside is that only Google has access to Google search queries, so most public health researchers don't work at search engine's, so this is not really data that they can use and play with.
So last year Aaron Colletta discovered that you can replicate this, but instead of search queries you can use Twitter.
So this is great because Twitter data is public for the most part.
It's easier to get.
And also tweets are a little bit longer.
They contain more information, they have more context.
People have a history of tweets.
So not only is the public, but we think this data might be a little bit more useful and there might be more information that we can get out of this.
So I'll mention.
Google is not the only one to do this.
Other search engine's other datasets, other countries.
This these experiments have been replicated and it's been shown again and again that you can in fact correlate.
Data from the web and the social web with health epidemics.
So we think there's something to this.
I also want to note just this year alone, since we wrote this paper, we've seen at least three other papers that have looked at health and Twitter.
So two of them again confirmed you can measure the rate of the flu.
Twitter.
And another study also looked at tobacco use in Twitter.
So we think this is becoming a very popular research area.
Not only are data mining researchers excited by this, but also we've talked to a lot of health researchers who are also excited by this.
So.
Where I work differs from previous work rather than just focusing on one specific piece of information, such as the rate of the flu.
We decided to take a more high level approach.
So.
Rather than looking for one disease, we just want to explore what diseases are even talked about in Twitter.
So instead of using supervised models to look for one particular.
Piece of information we rely on unsupervised and semi supervised models.
So we want to discover what is out there and then once we do that.
Then we can start drilling deeper and looking at you know trends, overtime trends over space and so on.
So.
Before we can do any of this, of course we have to figure out which tweets are actually about health, because any given tweet is probably about nothing.
Or nothing useful to us.
So it turned out just a very, very small sliver of the tweets were about health, so we need to filter this out.
As I have some examples of why simple keyword filtering is probably insufficient.
If you search for fever on Twitter, almost everything you get back will be about Justin Bieber.
Which.
Might tell us something about our mental health, but not the health we're interested in so.
We're going to use machine learning to filter out these false positives, and then once we drill down to the set of tweets that are about health, then we'll group them further by disease.
So we started with.
2 billion tweets and then we use the keyword filter with about 30,000 health related keywords that we scraped from a variety of sites.
And this pruned our set down to only 12 million tweets that we considered candidates.
So then we filtered this down further by training a classifier.
So we took about 5000 tweets that we labeled using M Turk.
Essentially, we just wanted to label them as about health or not about health, and we also wanted to filter out.
Ads about dieting and things that look like they're about health but not really about the users health.
So in the end we ended up with 1.6 million tweets that our classifier labeled as being about health with an estimated precision of 90%.
So now we have this corpus of tweets that we believe to be about health.
So like I said.
Now we want to group them by disease, so just knowing if something is about health might not be useful, but it's a starting point.
If we knew that a tweet was about the flu or allergies, that would be useful.
So we're going to use a topic model to group these, so I said we don't have any assumptions about what diseases are out there.
We're trying to explore this, so we're going to use an unsupervised model to do this.
Additionally, we add some structure to this model over traditional topic models to incorporate symptom and treatment features.
So the hope is that this extra information will help us cluster these tweets by disease rather than rather than some other topic.
So.
Topic models.
Which I won't go into too much detail.
They are so popular these days.
I'm sure many people are familiar with him.
Essentially, they're a probabilistic model.
To explain text.
So the idea is each document in a corpus is some mixture of topics and then each topic is associated with a distribution over words.
And then these topic assignments are a hidden variable.
Which is why this is unsupervised, so the hope is that you can infer these parameters automatically and you'll end up with word distributions that form hopefully semantically coherent topics.
So in our model, like I said, we're going to add some structure specific to looking for diseases.
So in our model, we assume that each tweet is about an ailment or a medical condition.
So like I said, we've already filtered our data down to tweets that we believe to be about health, so this is a reasonable assumption.
Then each word in the tweet.
Can come from one of two sources, so each word can either be a background word or a general topic that's not about health.
Or the word can be specific to the element.
So for example, at the bottom you see this tweet, flu, runny nose, headache, Advil, home sick, watching TV.
So the first half of this tweet is definitely about the ailment there about the flu.
Whereas home, sick watching TV is not really about health, it's just extra information, so the hope is that our model can filter these out as being general non health words.
So.
If a word does come from the element, we then break it down further into three facets, which we call aspects.
So these are general words, symptoms or treatments.
So again, adding the symptoms and treatment structure to the model.
Helps filter out.
Words that are about a disease with identifiable symptoms of treatments in which word.
Certain general words.
And.
As input, we assume that we've already tag our corpus with the symptoms and treatment labels.
So to do that we scrape again medical websites.
To compile a Dictionary of symptoms and treatments so we've tagged, for example, runny nose, headache and Advil will already be tagged as being symptoms.
In the in the case of runny nose and headache or a treatment in the case of Advil.
So this slide formalizes the model assumptions I just stated, so we end up with what we call the ailment topic aspect model.
So this extends the standard topic model, so each tweet is associated with a hidden variable A which denotes the ailment.
Which is drawn from some distribution.
Each tree also has some distribution over general topics, as in a standard topic model.
And then you also have this switching variable X to determine if a word comes from the element, or if it's a general topic word.
So the generative story is that for each word you choose whether it comes from a topic or an ailment.
If it comes from a topic, you sample that topic and then you generate the word from that distribution.
If it comes from the ailment.
Then you you generate the word by sampling that word from the ailment distribution, and each ailment indexes three different multinomial's for the three aspects.
So each element has a distribution over general words, a distribution over symptoms in a distribution over treatments, and I'll show an example in a minute which should make this more clear.
So.
We can learn these hidden parameters using Gibbs sampling.
And then in the end.
We end up with clusters that we hope represent diseases or ailments.
So to find out if that was true, we gave our output to two annotators.
And for each cluster, they labeled it as being either a coherent disease or not.
And they agree that 15 out of the 20 did in fact represent coherent diseases.
And so these 15 elements are what we're going to use in further experiments.
So here's an example.
Of what our model learns.

Of either general word symptoms or treatments.

Has general words that aren't symptoms or treatments of allergies eyes allergic?
We see sneezing is a symptom and we see treatments of Benadryl and Claritin.
So we discovered 15 of these, which is great.
Previous work only looked at, for example, the flu or tobacco use, or a few specific things.
So now we have a model that can automatically learn these, so the hope is that we can.
Discover much broader patterns than what we've seen in previous work.
So now that we have this corpus.
We've identified tweets that are about health, and we've grouped them even further by disease.
So the next question is, what can we do with this?
So previous work, for example, looked at the flu rate overtime, so that's certainly something we'd like to look at and compare against.
So we decide to go further and we also look at time as well as geography.
And then I mentioned before that tweets have more information than search queries for example.
They have more Contacts.
They have more information, so we wanted to see if we can go a little bit deeper.
So one way we did that is by analyzing what treatments people are using for their diseases.

So there's nothing new here, but we wanted to see how well our model compares.
So this.
What shows are rate of the flu element that we detected with our model against.
CDC data in the United States.
And we found a 96% correlation.
So this is good.
This is a quantitative way to measure that our model seems to be capturing something meaningful.
Another thing I want to know is that our model is fully unsupervised.
We didn't tell it to look for the flu, we just told it to look for diseases, and one of those happened to be the flu.
And it happens to correspond with the real world pretty well.
So that's exciting, but what else?
We have a richer model.
We have 15 elements, So what other information can we learn?
So one thing we looked at.
What is the rate of elements?
Over geography.
So for 200,000 of these tweets, we were able to identify the US state of the user.

With that information, we decided to look at seasonal allergies, so we chose allergies because.
There's a different allergy season at different times of the year, but also in different parts of the United States.
So intuitively, our model should be able to capture that if it's doing what we expect.
So this is a map of the US.
With allergy rates in February, so a darker shade indicates a higher rate of allergies.
The states with best lines are states for which we didn't have enough data to make a reliable estimate.
So states like Montana and Wyoming.
Um?
So you can see by looking at this that it makes some sense, so it's still winter.
Some trees are starting to pollinate and some trees are still frozen.
Depending on where you live, so we see in the South the rates are starting to go up, but in much of the North you still see a much lower rate of allergies.
On the other hand.
We come to April, so now allergy season is in full swing.
Everyone is suffering everywhere.
But you can see now that actually some states that started earlier are now no longer the worst.
Now the Midwest and the Northeast seem to be the worst.

So now.
In the June, things have died down a bit.
